Incident.Summary: Numerous complaints for a reckless driver. Several traffic infractions observed. Traffic stop conducted on vehicle. Driver was found to be in possession of CDS paraphernalia. Released on traffic citations.

IncidentSuppNarrative.NarrativeText:
Trooper J. Hicks # 7576
Maryland State Police BK: X
Date of incident: 09/01/2023
CC # 23-MSP- 030801

BWC/In-car
Note: There is no in-car camera footage. The computer system was malfunctioning on the date of this incident and could not be accessed. Body camera was functioning, however was delayed on activation due to being turned off during my court appearance. This call was received as I was entering my vehicle leaving court and my body worn camera was not turned on and fully activated until the vehicle was stopped (prior to making in-person contact).
  • https://mdsp.evidence.com/axon/evidence?evidence_id=c5ef23e5b83041d493be5b4aa630ac09&partner_id=5ed6a168304e40eb9a0cfb1a226ef1a1


Suspect/Offender/Driver
Name: Adam Richard Necessary
DOB: 05/09/1985
MD SDX: MD10273009636

Victims
Name: State of Maryland

Officers Training/Experience:
  • *Trained in administering Standardized Field Sobriety Tests through the Eastern Shore Criminal Justice Academy and National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA). 2015.
  • Trained in administering Standardized Field Sobriety Tests through the Maryland State Police and National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA).2022.
  • Trained and certified to operate Radar and Lidar through the Maryland State Police.
  • NHTSA certified in Advanced Roadside Impaired Driving Enforcement (A.R.I.D.E).
  • CDS detection, recognition, packaging, distribution, classification and indicator training from ESCJA police academy (2015) and Maryland State Police Academy (2022).
  • Gangs 101
  • Basic SWAT School (2017)
  • IED (Improvised Explosive Device) detection, recognition, familiarization and scene management procedures. (2017).
  • *MPCTC Basic Instructor (general instructor/ defensive tactics)
  • Numerous CDS arrests and convictions in Wicomico County, Maryland Courts as a previous Police Officer/ Detective with the Salisbury Police Department.
  • Seven (7) years as a Salisbury City, Maryland Police Officer/ Detective. Lead investigator/Assisted in numerous high-profile cases to include: Thefts, robberies, burglaries, homicides, fraud, prohibited firearm possession, firearm possession, assaults, sexual assaults etc. Written/Assisted with numerous search and seizure warrants. Interviewed numerous suspects charged with various crimes. Numerous convictions in the District and Circuit Courts for Wicomico County, Maryland.

Processing/Property:
  • MSP 67
  • MSP PH form
  • Clear glass smoking device (crack pipe) containing trace amounts of crack cocaine. (Submitted as evidence and for testing).
Assignment:
On 09/01/2023, I was working my regular scheduled day shift patrol assignment in Somerset County, Maryland. I was utilizing vehicle X-30 as my regular assigned patrol vehicle was being receiving maintenance.

Narrative:
This report has been prepared based upon the observations of this trooper and/or those of other troopers relative to the offense(s). The facts contained herein are intended solely to give the prosecuting authority a basic understanding of the facts pertaining to this case. The facts contained herein are not intended to be an exhaustive recitation of the facts pertaining to pretrial or trial issues. Instead, this trooper anticipates that during the pretrial proceedings in this case, the prosecutor will take the opportunity to interview this trooper in order to ascertain any and all relevant facts which might be the subject of this troopers' testimony during court proceedings.

Narrative/ Statement of events:
                On 09/01/2023 at approximately 1421 hours, I was assigned to day shift patrol leaving the Somerset County District Court building. Immediately upon turning on my radio a broadcast was transmitted by MSP Princess Anne. This broadcast (BOLO) was for a blue Dodge pickup that was driving recklessly. Dispatch advised that several citizens called the MSP Princess Anne Barrack and complained about the listed vehicle crossing the fog line and driving “all over the road”. One of these complainants was a Maryland State Police Crime Scene Technician. MSP Dispatch advised that the vehicle in question is traveling on northbound US RT 13 in the area of Peggyneck Rd.

                At this time, I began traveling northbound on US RT 13 to search for said vehicle. I ultimately located the vehicle just north of Loretta Rd and began following it. While following the vehicle, I observed it to cross the fog line numerous times. At one point, the vehicle drove over the rumble strips for approximately 8 seconds. I then activated my emergency equipment (overhead front/rear) lights and attempted to conduct a traffic stop on the vehicle. The driver continued driving northbound on US RT 13. While driving, he crossed over the fog line by approximately 6-8 feet. The driver began looking back at me through the rear-view mirror along with turning around and looking at me out of the back window. I then began activating my vehicle emergency siren due to the vehicle not pulling over after having ample opportunities to do so in a safe location. The vehicle continued traveling while crossing over the fog line until it passed Flower Hill Church Rd where it began to slow down. The vehicle ultimately came to a stop approximately 200 yards north of Flower Hill Church Rd. Once the vehicle came to a stop, the driver continued made a quick lunge towards the center of the vehicle from the driver's seat and began reaching into the center console/floor. Immediately upon doing this the driver stared back at me through the rear center window. I know through my training knowledge and experience that individuals whom make hasty movements during traffic stops are commonly attempting to search for, conceal, tamper with, or destroy contraband items within their vehicle.  At this time, I gave loud verbal commands for the driver to place both of his hands out of the driver side window so that I can easily see them. The driver initially cooperated, however brought his right hand back inside the vehicle and appeared to be handling something in the center of the vehicle. I then ordered the driver again to place both of his hands out of the window in which he complied. At this time, my body worn camera was able to be activated.

                I then made contact with the driver who was later identified as Adam Richard Necessary (05/09/1985) by his Maryland Driver's License. Immediately upon speaking with Necessary, I observed him to have constricted pupils and I believed him to have an “amped up” demeanor. While speaking to him, he began fumbling with an unknown item that within the drivers side door pocket. Due to the numerous times, he was told to stop reaching for items within the vehicle and to keep his hands visible, I opened his door for my safety to observe what he was fumbling with. I then observed several “mini liquor bottles” in the driver side door pocket. Upon further observation, one of these bottles appeared to be half empty. At this time, 1SGT Daum and DFC Stewart of the Somerset County Sheriff's Office arrived to assist. Trooper Bynum and Trooper C. Brown also arrived on scene to assist. I then asked Necessary to exit the vehicle and submit to field sobriety tests. This request appeared to have made Necessary irate. He immediately slammed his door shut and locked the door. This behavior was appeared to be consistent with that of someone who is about to flee from a traffic stop. Due to this, I requested for the Deputy's to place “Stop Sticks” under the vehicle's rear driver side tire. It should be noted that Necessary ultimately cooperated and exited the vehicle.
Standardize Field Sobriety Tests (SFST)
Trooper Bynum conducted all SFST on Necessary. Trooper Bynum advised that he does not believe Necessary was impaired by alcohol, however agreed that he is displaying indicators of impairment due to his “amped up” behavior and constricted pupils. Trooper Bynum did not believe that Necessary performed poorly enough on SFST for him to be arrested for CDS DUI/DWI.

               
Plain view observations/ PC search
While Trooper Bynum was conducting SFTS, 1SGT Daum observed a clear glass smoking device in plain view that he knew through his training knowledge and experience to be a “crack pipe” through the passenger side front window. He advised the “crack pipe” was on the floor between the passenger door and front passenger seat. I then looked through the window and observed said crack pipe. I also immediately recognized this device to be a “crack pipe”. I know through my training knowledge and experience that “crack pipes” are used to smoke crack cocaine.
Based on the above observations, Trooper Brown and I conducted a probable cause search of the vehicle. During the search the following items were located:
  • Numerous mini liquor bottles of various brand/flavor. Some were empty and appeared to be old. (observation)
  • Numerous lighters that had the flame adjuster removed. I know through my training knowledge and experience that people who remove this device from their lighter commonly use it to heat the end of the crack pipe for easier inhalation. (observation)
  • One (1), clear glass smoking device “crack pipe”, packed with “chor boy”. I know that “chor boy” is a common filtration device used within crack pipes. (Seized and submitted into MSP property).

Traffic stop findings/conclusion
                Due to limited manpower working at the time of this incident, I seized the “crack pipe” and submitted it into MSP property for further chemical testing at the MSP forensic lab. Necessary was ultimately released on traffic citations for the infractions observed. He was informed that an application for charges will be done once the results from the MSP forensic lab have returned. Due to his driving behavior, constricted pupils and the open liquor bottles within the vehicle, we requested for Necessary to contact a friend/relative to pick him up. He advised he was able to contact someone that will pick him up from How Sweet It Is (3601 Stockyard Rd). Necessary advised he will walk to this location and wait for his ride to arrive.

Case status:
                I respectfully request this case be suspended until the results from the MSP forensic lab are returned.


All events occurred in Somerset County, Maryland.

IncidentProperty.Description: One (1), clear glass smoking device "crack pipe" containing trace amounts of crack cocaine.
